text: Since no one in the class was a 60% free throw shooter, Miquel suggests that they use a spinner to determine the probabilities of getting a score of 0, 1, or 2. The blue area represents the chance of making the basket, a Hit. The blue area represents the chance of missing the basket, a Miss.

Make a prediction.

  • Is it most likely that Nishi will score 0 points, 1 point, or 2 points?

SOLUTION BEGIN

Predictions will vary. Many people predict that 1 point is the most likely.

Equipment

  • A circle with 60% indicating a Hit and 40% indicating a Miss
  • Paper clips or blank plastic spinners

Directions (with a partner or small group)

  • Simulate Nishiâ€™s one-and-one situation using the 60/40 spinner
  • Spin 20 times
  • Record the result of each trial.

Analyze the data

  • Based on your results, what is the experimental probability that Nishi will score 0 points? 1 point? 2 points?

SOLUTION BEGIN

Results will vary.

Students are likely to have more hits than misses.

One possible result from a group is: 0 points (seven times); 1 point (five times); and 2 points (8 times).

For the results reported above, experimental probability is:

P(0 points) = 7/20 = 35%

P(1 point) = 5/20 = 25%

P(2 points) = 8/20 = 40%

SOLUTION BEGIN

Answers will vary based on their predictions.
